posts.name: vegas_jen
posts.cooked: We have VEX Planetary gearboxes, but they are not rated to have such a high gear reduction with Falcons. These are out of stock on REV. We need 2, plus backups. We will pay for shipping, and of course the product, if you have these and are not using them this season.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: AndyMark Falcon Sport Gearboxes are in-stock in 100:1, for what it’s worth.

posts.name: MyName
posts.cooked: Not to hijack the thread, but we were wondering what the highest gear ratio configuration you can do on a REV maxplanetary gearbox is. Can you keep adding slices in perpetuity?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: I mean, you can physically add as many stages as you want as long as you have long enough bolts to hold it together, though we can assume at some point it becomes impractical.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
The following torque measurements are for a static load condition (i.e. not moving). The torques listed are for the output of the stage.

3:1 Cartridge - Tested to 290Nm [2567in*lbs] (no failure)

4:1 Cartridge - Fails at 270Nm [2390in*lbs]

5:1 Cartridge - Fails at 240Nm [2124in*lbs]

1/2" Hex Socket Output - Fails at 250Nm [2213in*lbs]

posts.name: REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO
posts.cooked:
So the Answer is Yes and no.  Physically you can continue to stack the stages and make really big reductions, but as posted above each of our stages has a ultimate failure point, so once the output torque crosses that line you are likely to see failures.

So what ratio you can use depends on which motor you use and it’s loading conditions on your robot.

We have published load ratings, that you are good with every motor upto 125:1 but I have seen many teams go higher than that with both success (and some failures)

posts.name: MyName
posts.cooked: Thank you. I saw the load ratings for up to 125, which made me wonder if 125 was the max one could go. We have a gearbox that we have put to 300:1 to move an arm joint. We have also added helper springs, so we may not need that high of a ratio, but I wanted to see if that was even a possibility before we ran it and found out it wasn’t.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO
posts.cooked: if you are going to go to 300, make sure you figure out ways to ensure your motor doesn’t stall against a hard stop. Also decoupling shock from the gearbox by using chain or belts as your final stage will also help not kill the gearbox. You might also want to consider using steel hex shafts instead of aluminum as you very well may twist the aluminum shaft to failure.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: 7042 says steel might not be enough; apparently they’ve twisted a couple steel hex shafts.
